reviewText: Young Mark is played by Matt Kesslar who is quietly in love with a girl.  However, her strong-willed, nasty father, Fergus, played by Patrick Bergen  has decided he will "take the head" of anyone courting his  daughter.  Not afraid, but also not stupid, Mark sets out to prove his  manhood, hoping to impress cantankerous Fergus.  Since he is a savvy but  struggling cattle farmer, Mark refuses to be sucked into the fraudulent  scheme of accepting half what his herd is worth.  He undertakes an  unprecedented 40 mile cattle drive, hoping to get his full price. The drive  is made interesting by dangerous attempts at sabotage by jealous ranchers,  and the presence of Brenda Fricker as his headstrong, feisty aunt. Brenda  is, again, excellent in this role. In spite of danger, Mark's love and his  business knowledge make him even more determined to end up with coins in  his pocket and a wife on his arm.The only reason I deducted one star  is I felt the movie needed a tad more depth in the story line. Hallmark  Hall of Fame chose a warm, family movie in this one...and the scenery is  second to none.
summary: A light love story set in gorgeous Ireland scenery!

reviewText: I used to rent this every time I thought of it, so decided to buy it.  Based on John B. Keane's novel that brings to life the people he knew during the World War II era, this is the story of a brave young man named Mark Doran (Matt Keeslar) who goes from boyhood to manhood by attempting a cattle drive with his aunt Maeve (Brenda Fricker), a plucky clergyman (George Hern), and a host of other friends who simply want fair prices for their cattle than they're getting at home.The greedy local merchant tries to upset the ambitious party, but lots of surprises, quick thinking, and good humor help them move forward on their 40-mile journey.  What is wonderful about this story is the warmth and humor brought to life in the individualization of the characters, and the overall message that collective good can win the day against those who try to bully others to their will.  Several humorous moments fill the story, but I won't give them all away, except for the way Mark always backs down when Fergus Mullaney (Patrick Bergen) even catches him giving his precious daughter Annie (Nancy St. Alban), whom he wants to marry sidelong glances.Not only does Mark learn to be a strong man who can take charge of a band of travelling farmers and cattle, he also learns to find the strength to face Annie's father.  A feelgood movie that makes you care for all the characters in it, it is nice to see Hallmark stick close to the book and put the story before the Irish scenery which is undeniably gorgeous.  It's a great movie for the whole family with a little something in it for everyone, and it also teaches you the positive outcome of standing up for something you believe in. Kudos to Hallmark for doing such a superior job!
summary: Durango is Hallmark's Best Film Presentation.

reviewText: Without a doubt this score is one of the outstanding pieces written for any television movie.  It rivals and in many respects exceed the legendary score of "Lonesome Dove".  Mark McKenzie is one of the remarkable  composers of film music although little is heard of his works.  The score  of "Durango" is uplifting, inspirational and vivid in the telling  of the story.  Once you listen to it I guarantee you will be inexorably  hooked and it will become one of your favorite works.
summary: You won't believe it until you listen to it.
